subject: Re: [junit] Unit Testing question
msgSnippet: Oh great, now we ll have that flame fest over here again! I ll get the first shot in and then hide while the mighty J.B. strides down from atop of his mountain
messageBody:
Oh great, now we'll have that flame fest over here again!

I'll get the first shot in and then hide while the mighty J.B. strides
down from atop of his mountain to correct us all. ;-)

A unit test should test a unit. A unit is whatever concept or portion
of functionality makes sense within the context of your code base.

In some systems, a unit test might test a method, in others it might
test a group of inter-operative objects.

For example. I'm writing a small string handling library and each
method of my library gets it's own test. Whereas at the day job, I
often find myself testing either a whole object or a group of objects.
It really does depend on what makes sense for your system and the
granularity of the concepts and functionality that it contains.

Perhaps this is why J.B. prefers the term "programmer tests" instead
of unit tests. Because no one can agree on what a unit actually is,
but most programmers know what needs to be tested.

OK, everyone else gets a turn now.

Simon
